metadata.title: Fe/N/S-composited hierarchically porous carbons with optimized surface functionality, composition and nanoarchitecture as electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction

S0021-9517(17)30177-X 10.1016/j.jcat.2017.05.011 Fig. 1 Proposed mechanism for the synthesis of Fe(x)N/S-PAD hierarchically porous carbon electrocatalysts. Fig. 2 N2 sorption isotherms (BET curves) of (a) Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD, (d) Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD, and (g) Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD. Insets in (a), (d) and (g) show the pore size distributions of corresponding samples, determined using the BJH (2～60nm) and DFT (0～2nm) methods, (b, c, e, f, and h) TEM images of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (x =0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, respectively), and (i) Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD-(w/o silica). Scale bars in TEM images: 50nm; Scale bars (insets in (h)): 10nm. Fig. 3 (a)Raman spectra of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD samples; (b) XPS spectra of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD, Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD samples. Fig. 4 High-resolution C 1s XPS spectra of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (a), Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD (b) and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (c); High-resolution Fe 2p XPS spectra of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (d), Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD (e) and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (f); High-resolution S 2p XPS spectra of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (g), Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD (h) and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (i); High-resolution N 1s XPS spectra of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (j), Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD (k) and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (l). Fig. 5 (a) Percentage contents of total S and Fe contents of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (x =0.05, 0.5, 1.5) catalysts; (b) Percentage contents of total N and the BET surface areas of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (X=0.05, 0.5, and 1.5) catalysts; (c) Fe contents and current densities at 0.8V for Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (x =0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5) catalysts. The values of Fe contents in these catalysts were obtained with ICP-MS. Fig. 6 (a) Cyclic voltammograms of a glassy carbon (GC) disk electrode coated by Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst (loading: 100µgcm−2), recorded in N2- and O2-saturated 0.1M KOH, respectively, at a potential scan rate of 50mVs−1; (b) Linear sweep voltammograms of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (x =0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5) catalysts on a GC rotating disk electrode (rotation rate: 1600rpm) in O2-saturated 0.1M KOH at a scan rate of 5mVs−1; (c) Linear sweep voltammograms of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD with 100µgcm−2 and 500µgcm−2 loadings, and Pt/C catalyst (20wt.% Pt/C, loading: 100µgcm−2Pt/C), (d) Percentages of H2O2 produced and ORR electron transfer numbers catalyzed by Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD and Pt/C catalysts, respectively. Fig. 7 (a) Cyclic voltammograms of a GC electrode coated by Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst (loading: 100µgcm−2), recorded in N2- and O2-saturated 0.1M HClO4, respectively, at a scan rate of 50mVs−1; (b) Linear sweep voltammograms of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) catalysts on a GC rotating disk electrode (rotation rate: 1600rpm) in O2-saturated 0.1M HClO4 at a scan rate of 5mVs−1(loading: 800µgcm−2); (c) Linear sweep voltammograms of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD with 100µgcm−2 and 800µgcm−2 loadings, and Pt/C catalyst (20wt.% Pt, loading: 100µgcm−2), (d) Percentages of H2O2 produced and ORR electron transfer numbers catalyzed by Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD and Pt/C catalyst. Fig. 8 Linear sweep voltammograms of Pt/C (a) and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (b) on a rotating disk electrode (1600rpm) before and after 5000 cycles in O2-saturated 0.1M HClO4 at a scan rate of 5mVs−1 (loading: 100µgcm−2 for Pt/C and 800µgcm−2for Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD, respectively); Linear sweep voltammograms of Pt/C (c) and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (d) on a rotating disk electrode (1600rpm) before and after 5000 cycles in O2-saturated0.1M KOH at a scan rate of 5mVs−1 (loading: 100µgcm−2 for both Pt/C and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD). Table 1 Elemental composition and texture properties of the catalysts. Catalysts Total surface N content (at.%) Surface content (at.%) of different N functionalities Total surface S content (at.%) Surface content (at.%) of different S functionalities N1 N2 N3 S1 S2 S3 Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD 10.35 3.66 4.85 1.84 0.32 0.14 0.04 0.14 Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD 10.09 5.22 3.69 1.18 0.52 0.25 0.06 0.21 Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD 4.84 2.45 2.03 0.35 0.51 0.37 0.08 0.06 Fe/N/S-composited hierarchically porous carbons with optimized surface functionality, composition and nanoarchitecture as electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction Mingjie Wu a b Qiaowei Tang b Fang Dong b Zhengyu Bai a ⁎ Lei Zhang c Jinli Qiao a b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang, Henan 453007, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions Ministry of Education Henan Normal University Xinxiang Henan 453007 China b College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Donghua University, 2999 Ren’min North Road, Shanghai 201620, China College of Environmental Science and Engineering Donghua University 2999 Ren’min North Road Shanghai 201620 China c Energy, Mining & Environment, National Research Council of Canada, Vancouver, BC, Canada Energy, Mining & Environment National Research Council of Canada Vancouver BC Canada ⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang, Henan 453007, China. School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions Ministry of Education Henan Normal University Xinxiang Henan 453007 China Graphical abstract Non-precious Fe/N/S-composited hierarchically porous carbon materials (Fe(x)/N/S-PAD, PAD: poly(acrylamide-co-diallyldimethyl ammonium chlor), x: the weight ratio of FeSO4 7H2O/PAD) are synthesized using a facile silica colloid template approach with FeSO4 7H2O as Fe and S sources, and PAD as N source, respectively. A simultaneous creation of porous structures and surface functionalities (Fe, N and S) of such catalysts is realized just by simply tuning the weight ratio of FeSO4 7H2O and PAD in the synthetic precursors. As a result, a series of catalyst samples with high oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity/stability are obtained, demonstrating the promotion role of FeSO4/PAD ratio in synthesizing high-performing catalysts. Particularly, a catalyst (Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD) with a trace Fe content down to 1.0wt.% is tested to be superior to a commercial Pt/C catalyst in alkaline media and exhibits impressive ORR performance in acidic media. Combined with characterization results such as TEM, Raman spectra, BET and XPS analysis, it is found that the well-defined micro- and meso-porous structure play the key role in enhancing catalytic ORR performance rather than the final total N contents in the carbon. Regarding the stability of such a catalyst, test using cyclic voltammetry for 5000 cycles in O2-saturated solution shows a negligible degradation rate when compared with Pt/C one, suggesting that this catalyst could be used for catalyzing the high-performing cathode ORR in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, alkaline fuel cells and metal–air batteries. Keywords Fe/N/S-composited hierarchically porous carbons Surface functionalities Oxygen reduction reaction Active-site formation and nature Fuel cells Metal-air batteries 1 Introduction Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is one of the necessary reactions in several important electrochemical energy technologies such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries. However, ORR takes place almost in the cathode with Pt/C catalyst exclusively because of it’s sluggish nature [1–4], which can be understood based on the high OO bond energy of oxygen (498kJmol−1), meaning that this double-bond is very difficult to be broken during the ORR. As yet, the high cost, intolerance to fuel crossover, and poor durability of the Pt/C catalyst in the fuel-cell environment can hardly meet the demands for the widespread commercialization of fuel cells [5–6]. Therefore, a successful large-scale and commercial implementation of these technologies requires the development of active, stable and low-cost ORR catalysts, preferably the catalysts which are free of precious metals. With respect to this, considerable research efforts in the last several decades have been devoted to the search for alternative non-precious catalysts with both high activity and stability. Among the non-precious catalysts explored, a wide range of heteroatom (N, S, Cl, B, P, Fe, and so on)mono- and co-doped carbon materials such as porous carbon foams [7], graphene [8], graphite [9], nanotubes (CNTs) [10] and their supported non-noble metal materials [11–12] have been studied for catalyzing oxygen reduction reaction. It has been reported that the doped/composited carbon materials with heteroatoms, serving as ORR catalysts or catalyst supports, can not only have more surface defects [13], but also possess more modulated catalytic sites [14]. However, most of these reported carbon-based catalysts are still inferior to the Pt/C catalyst in terms of ORR activity and stability especially in acidic media where most such a kind of catalysts can suffer from high overpotential and low durability [15]. Regarding non-precious metal catalysts, one family of the most promising ones is the Fe/N contained carbon materials (Fe/N-CMs) [16–19]. The critical feature related to the ORR activity of Fe/N-CMs was suggested to be the breakage of electroneutrality of the carbon atoms induced by nitrogen doping, which could result in a large electropositivity of carbon and consequently facilitate oxygen adsorption and reduction [20–21]. Moreover, both the ORR activity and stability of Fe/N-CMs could also be induced by the surface functionalities mainly the active N species which could bind with Fe ions to form the ORR active sites [17,22–27]. Although both Fe and N are critical to the active-site performance, the detailed mechanism for active-site formation and nature are still remained elusive. Therefore, it is particularly interesting to understand the influence of Fe and N on the catalyst’s chemical composition and the nature of ORR catalytic sites in order to rationally design and prepare high active and long durable Fe/N-CM catalysts. Besides the active sites, catalyst’s surface area and porous structure, which determine the accessible portion of active sites and the transport properties of ORR-relevant species, are also playing an important role in improving ORR performance [2,28]. In order to achieve high surface area and tunable pore sizes, the template method, a common and effective route, has been extensively employed to synthesize porous Fe/N-carbon catalysts [29]. As yet, the traditional template method for preparing porous carbons by direct pyrolyzing the mixture of nitrogen-containing carbon precursor, template and transition metal precursors has some difficulty in obtaining desirable high surface area as well as optimal pore sizes distribution, leading to limited exposure of the ORR active sites and also the relatively poor transport properties [30]. In addition, in the effort to enhance the ORR performance of Fe/N-CM catalysts, the existence of sulfur (S) in the as-prepared materials, induced during the synthesis using FeSO4 salt as one of the precursors, could be also observed to play a role in ORR catalysis [8]. In our previous work, we found that even a small amount of S in the catalyst, the ORR performance could be visibly affected [2]. To further study the roles of Fe, N and S in the ORR catalysts, in this work, we have synthesized Fe/N/S-composited carbon materials (Fe/N/S-CMs) using both FeSO4 7H2O and poly(acrylamide-co-diallyldimethyl ammonium chlor) (abbreviated as PAD) as the sources of Fe, N and S. In the synthesis, FeSO4 7H2O+silica colloid is used as joint template to facilitate the simultaneous formation of both porous structures and surface functionalities of the obtained catalysts. By effectively tuning the weight ratio of FeSO47H2O and PAD in the precursor solution, the catalysts (Fe/N/S-PAD) with a trace Fe content down to 1.0wt.% are obtained, which show both high ORR catalytic activity and long-term stability in both alkaline and acidic media. By varying initial FeSO4 7H2O/PAD weight ratios, we have studied the effect of FeSO4 7H2O on the catalyst performance, surface chemical composition, morphology and structural characteristics. As observed, when the initial FeSO4 7H2O/PAD weight ratio is higher than 0.25, the final Fe contents in the catalysts are almost saturated, however, the activities have a significant difference from each other. Moreover, the combined analyzing of TEM, Raman spectra, BET and XPS indicated a strong synergistic effect between silica template and FeSO47H2O, which can not only greatly improve the porosity of Fe/N/S-PAD catalysts, but also dramatically optimize their surface functionalities. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of the Fe/N/S-PAD catalysts The fabrication of Fe/N/S-PAD hierarchically porous carbon catalysts involved a simple two-step graphitization of the impregnated carbon. The overall synthetic procedure is shown in Fig. 1 . In a typical approach, 5g of nano-silica (∼500nm) was added into 25g of 1.0M HCl and sonicated with vigorous stirring for ∼10min to obtain an uniform SiO2 colloid solution (16wt.%). 20.0g of poly(acrylamide-co-diallyldimethyl ammonium chlor) (PAD) solution (10wt.%, Sigma–Aldrich) was added into 42mL of 1.0M HCl with stirring for ∼5min to form a PAD solution. Then the pre-obtained SiO2 colloid solution was added drop-wisely into this PAD solution with vigorous stirring to form a homogeneous mixture (the PAD content was 40wt.% with respect to the silica). This process could make a spontaneous coating of adherent PAD layers on the SiO2 template. Then, a solution of FeSO4 7H2O solution was added into this mixture under stirring for more than 3h. By adding different amounts ofFeSO47H2O (with ratios of FeSO47H2O/PAD=0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5, respectively), a series of precursors samples could be obtained. Then the resulting viscous solutions were dried for 48h at 85°C. The obtained solids were ground to fine powders using an agate mortar and, then pyrolyzed at 800°C for 1h under nitrogen atmosphere with a temperature ramp rate of 20°C per minute. The SiO2 in the samples was leached out using excess amount of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) (4M) solution for 48h and the resulting powders were washed by deionized water for neutralization, and dried for overnight. To remove a redundant phase, mainly unreacted metallic Fe compounds, the samples were all acid-leached using 0.5M H2SO4 at 85°C for 8h and dried for five hours. Finally, the catalysts were heat-treated under a nitrogen atmosphere at 800°C for another 1h. These obtained catalysts are designated as Fe(x)/N/S-PAD (where x =0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, which are the ratios of FeSO4 7H2O/PAD in the synthesis solution). To elucidate the joint effect of template agent of colloidal silica andFeSO47H2O, Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD was also prepared without using the silica template, named Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD-(w/o-silica). 2.2 Material characterization Images of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were obtained with a high-resolution Hitachi JEM-2100 system at operating voltage of 200kV. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to determine the specific surface area by measuring the adsorption/desorption of nitrogen using an Autosorb-1 volumetric adsorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments, USA). The specific surface area was calculated using the adsorption data at a relative pressure range of 0.05–0.3. The pore size distribution curves were calculated by the nonlocal density functional theory. Raman spectra were obtained edusing microscopic confocal Raman spectrometer with a 633nm laser excitation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were performed using a RBD-upgraded PHI-5000C ECSA system (PerkinElmer) with an Al K X-ray anode source. 2.3 Electrode preparation and electrochemical measurements To measure the catalytic activity of the above synthesized catalysts, the catalyst ink was prepared by ultrasonically mixing 2.0mg catalyst with 0.4mL of isopropyl alcohol and 0.1mL of 0.5wt.% Nafion® for more than 30min. Then 6.2 μL (low loading, 100 µgcm−2) or 31.0 μL (high loading, 500 µgcm−2) of the resulting suspension was dropped onto the pre-cleaned glassy carbon disk electrode surface (6.25mm diameter), and dried at room temperature to form a uniform catalyst layer. For comparison, a commercially available 20wt.% platinum on Vulcan carbon black (Pt/C from E-tek) was used as the baseline, and its catalyst ink and electrode were prepared under the same conditions as those for the studied catalysts, and the Pt/C loading is100 µgcm−2 for all electrochemical measurements. The ORR performances of the obtained Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts were evaluated on a CHI Electrochemical Station (760D), using a standard three-electrode cell. All electrochemical tests were carried out in either O2-saturated or N2-saturated electrolyte solution controlled at room temperature. In order to subtract the background capacitive current, rotating disk electrode (RDE) and rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) testing were performed under the same conditions in an N2-saturated electrolyte. The onset potential was defined as the potential at which the background subtracted current density was equal to −0.1mAcm−2 [2]. In the measurements, the catalyzed RDE or RRDE was used as the working electrode, a platinum wire as the counter electrode and a saturated calomel electrode as the reference electrode. In this paper, all potentials were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale. Before each measurement for cyclic voltammograms (CV), current-voltage curves of rotating-disk electrode or chronoamperometry, the electrolyte solution was purged with high purity nitrogen or oxygen for at least 30min to ensure saturation. The peroxide percentage (H2O2 %) was determined from RRDE measurements based on the disk current (Id ) and ring current (Ir ) via the following Eq. (1): (1) H 2 O 2 % = 100 × 2 I r / N I d + I r / N The ORR electron transfer number (n) was based on the following Eq. (2): (2) n = 4 I d I d + I r / N where N (= 0.37) is the current collection efficiency of the Pt ring, which was calibrated with a N2-saturated 10mM K3Fe(CN)6 +0.1M KOH electrolyte solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 1Morphology and structural characterization In order to understand the morphologies of the synthesized catalysts, the microstructures of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts were first examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. 2 (a–h), the porosity of obtained Fe(x)/N/S-PAD can be enhanced greatly along with increasing the weight ratio of FeSO47H2O/PAD, confirming that FeSO47H2O can be used as activating agent to promote the formation of porous structure. When the ratio is increased to about 1.5, the as-prepared Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst shows a large interconnected mesoporous system with a diameter of ～20nm, which is resided on the surface of catalyst (Fig.2(h)). The change of morphology with increasing amount of FeSO47H2O is consistent with a recent observation that Fe could act as an active agent for the formation of graphene-like structure [15]. Unlike Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst, Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD-(w/o silica) synthesized without using the template of colloidal silica shows a much lower porosity when compared to Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD, and only a more compact and aggregated structure is found (Fig.2(i)). This suggests that only the joint effect of template agent of colloidal silica and the activating agent of FeSO47H2O can contribute to the formation of the complicated mesoporous system. It should be mentioned that the iron nanoparticles couldn’t be observed by TEM(inset in Fig.2(h)) in this catalyst probably due to the extremely low Fe content, suggesting that Fe species on the surface of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD have been almost removed by the leaching processes using sodium hydroxide solution and then H2SO4. The textural properties of the Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts were investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. It can be seen that the N2 sorption isotherm of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (Fig.2(g)) shows a rapid rise at low pressure region and much more remarkable hysteresis loops when compared to both Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD and Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD at a relatively high pressure (Fig.2(a) and (d)), indicating that there exist a large number of both irregular micropores and mesoporous. This result is in a well agreement with the TEM observation. Using these plots, the BET surface area of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst could be calculated to be 852m2/g, which is much higher than that of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (651m2/g). This could be attributed to the volume expansion as indicated in Fig. 1. The multimodal pore size distribution (PSD) plots according to calculation using both the Barrett-Joyer-Halenda(BJH) (2～60nm) and Density-Functional-Theory (DFT) (0～2nm) methods indicate that the hierarchical porous Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst possesses both micropore and mesopore centered at 0.9 and 20nm, respectively, as indicated by the insets in Fig.2(g), whereas the Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD only shows a broad pore size distribution in the range of micropore (0～2nm), and almost has no mesoporous size distribution (Fig.2(a)). These results further prove that the simultaneous introduction of silica and FeSO47H2O plays a key role in fabricating mesoporous carbon-based materials and thus increasing the surface area. The high BET surface area and the unique porous structure of such catalysts could offer a desirable combination of highly accessible surface area and the efficient transport path, significantly promoting ORR catalytic activity. Raman spectroscopy was also used to analyze the graphitic structure of carbon materials. Several characteristic peaks around 1339 and 1558cm−1could be observed, as shown in Fig. 3 (a). The band at 1339cm−1 (D band) is associated with the presence of a disordered carbon structure, and the band at 1588cm−1 (G band) corresponds to the stretching mode of CC bonds of typical graphite [31]. The relative intensity ratio of G and D bands (I D /I G ) can be used to assess the degree of graphitization in carbon material. A lower I D /I G value indicates a higher graphitization degree [32]. Nevertheless, in all spectra, the D band is much stronger than the G band with I D /I G ratio being higher than 3, indicating the presence of a large number of defects in the Fe(x)/N/S-PAD samples [33]. Note, the I D /I G value of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD is 3.26, which is clearly lower than that of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (4.42), indicating that the former has a higher graphitic structure and good conductivity than the latter, which could facilitate a fast electron transport during the electrochemical process. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to investigate the change of surface chemical composition and binding situation. As shown in Fig.3(b), the survey scans for Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts show the existence of C 1s, N 1s and O 1s. Fe could not be detected in the wide-scan spectra due to its extremely low content in these catalysts. To further demonstrate the effect on the surface chemical composition and chemical state in the Fe(x)/N/S-PAD samples, narrow scans of C1s, N1s, S2p and Fe2p peaks are analyzed in details (Fig. 4 ). It can be seen that S2p can be obviously detected in the narrow-scan spectra although some error may occur. According to the C 1s, N 1s and O1s and S2p spectra of the three samples, the calculated atomic percentages of different N and S (based on the peak areas in the survey scans) are summarized in Fig. 5 and Table 1 . The values of Fe contents in these catalysts were obtained with ICP-MS (Fig.5(a) and (c)). These results indicate that both Fe and S species have been also successfully incorporated into the carbon. As shown in Fig. 4(a–c), the half-peak width of C 1s spectrum becomes narrower with increasing the weight ratio of FeSO47H2O and PAD, implying an enhanced graphitic degree. Besides, the Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD shows a no obvious negative shift in band position of C1s (from 284.42±0.1eV to 283.98±0.1eV) (Fig.4(c)), which may be attributed to the change of chemical bond, reflecting the effect of FeSO4 7H2O on the chemical composition. Fig. 4(d–f) shows the Fe 2p spectral region for Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts. In this case, the signal is not clear enough due to the very low content of Fe and large amount of noise. As shown in Fig.5(c), when the initial ratio of FeSO4 7H2O/PAD is higher than 1.0, the final Fe contents of Fe(1.0)/N/S-PAD and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD are merely about 0.9wt.%. Regarding S 2p spectra, all the high resolution S 2p peaks of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD prepared with different ratios of FeSO4 7H2O/PAD can also be resolved into three different peaks at the binding energies of 163.9, 165.1 and 168.5eV (Fig. 4 (g–i)), respectively. Similar to literature [33,34], the former two peaks can be ascribed to the reported 2p3/2 (S1) and 2p1/2 (S2) positions of thiophene-S owing to their spin-orbit coupling, whereas the peak at 168.5eV should be attributed to some oxidized sulfur (S3). It is worth noting that the total amounts of S for Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD reach to 0.52% and 0.53%, respectively, which are much higher than that of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (0.4%), while the final S contents in the catalysts are almost saturated when the initial FeSO4 7H2O/PAD weight ratio is higher than 0.5 (Fig. 5 (a)). Although the heteroatoms S (χ=2.58) is very close to C (χ=2.55), S atom can change carbon’s spin and charge distributions due to the formation of thiophene sulfur and oxidized sulfur etc., accordingly, the adjacent C atoms with high spin densities and positive charge are conducive to oxygen adsorption and reduction [8]. Fig. 4(j–l) shows the high-resolution N1s peak of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD sample, which could be further deconvoluted into three different peaks, corresponding to pyridinic-N (N1), graphitic-N (N2) and pyridine-N-oxide(N3), respectively [35]. Obviously, the peak intensities are significantly different from each other. For Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD sample, there is also a gradual negative shift in band position of both pyridinic-N(N1) and graphitic-N (N2) (from 399.3±0.1eV to 398.9±0.1eV for graphitic-N, and from 400.7±0.1eV to 400.0±0.1eV for pyridinic-N). This may be related to the relatively more graphitic N and pyridinic N atoms or more Fe-Nx formation in the carbon network. The relative sum amount of pyridinic and graphitic Nis reached to 91% in Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD sample, which is much higher than that in Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD (79%). As believed, both the pyridinic and graphitic N groups on the carbon substrate’s surface could play an important role in enhancing ORR activities [36,37]. Surprisingly, the total amount of N in the sample has a very opposite correlation with BET surface area (Fig. 5(b)). The Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD shows a highest BET surface area but a lowest total N amount. It can be understood that the heat-treatment during the catalyst synthesis at such high temperatures would burn off carbon significantly together with the elimination of nitrogen moieties that are originated from the nitrogen-enriched polymers. Contrary to this, it seems that the amount of S has a very positive correlation with Fe contents can be observed in Fig.5(a), which should be attributed to the formation of Fe-S bonds in the pyrolysis process [38,39]. Although the detail of surface chemistry occurring during pyrolysis in the presence of both silica and FeSO4 7H2O remains elusive, these results above clearly suggest that the FeSO4 7H2O can not only supply both Fe and S, but also improve the porosity of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD and dramatically restructure the catalyst’s surface functionalities, both of which are crucial for enhancing ORR activity. 3.2 Catalytic ORR activities of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts in alkaline electrolytes 3.2.1 Electrochemical measurements To demonstrate the electrocatalytic ORR activity of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts toward ORR in alkaline electrolyte, Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD sample was first measured in both N2- and O2-saturated 0.1M aqueous KOH electrolyte solution, respectively, using cyclic voltammetry at a scan rate of 50mVs−1 (Fig.6 (a)). For comparison, a commercial 20wt.% platinum catalyst (Pt/C) was used as the baseline measured at the same conditions. In the case of N2-saturated solution, cyclic voltammograms (CVs) in the potential range of 0.0 to 1.2V vs. RHE give a quasi-rectangular voltammogram with a small redox response due to the pseudo capacitive behavior of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (Fig.6(a)). In contrast, a profound cathodic ORR peak, centered at 0.81 V with a high reaction current of 2.2mAcm−2, is clearly observed when the electrolyte solution is saturated with O2. This ORR peak potential is very close to that of Pt/C (0.83V), indicating that this Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst has an ORR activity comparable to Pt/C. 3.2.2 Measurements by rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) To further quantitatively evaluate the catalytic ORR activity, Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts were tested using RRDE in O2-saturated 0.1M KOH electrolyte solution. Fig. 6(b) shows the effect of the weight ratio of FeSO47H2O and PAD on the catalysts’ ORR activity. It can be seen that the ORR activity of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts is significantly increased with increasing the weight ratio of FeSO47H2O/PAD. The Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD’s ORR activity is quite low and also has no well-defined limiting current plateau. However, when the weight ratio of FeSO47H2O/PAD is increased to higher than 1.0, both onset potential and half-wave potential are largely increased, and a comparatively well-defined mass-transfer-limited current plateau appears, suggesting that this catalyst has a much higher catalytic ORR activity than that of Fe(0.05)/N/S-PAD. The half wave potential (E 1/2) of the Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (500 µgcm−2) is 0.85V, which is 30mV more positive than that of commercial 20% Pt/C catalyst (Fig. 6(c)). Even at a low loading of 100 µgcm−2 (with a same loading of Pt/C), the Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD can still show a prominent ORR activity with an half-wave potential of 0.83V. It's worth noting that ORR activity have no directrelationship with Fe content and total N content. The amount of real effective active sites for carbon material depends on the optimized hierarchically porous structures and the high BET surface area (Fig. 5(b) and (c)). Normally, O2electroreduction to H2O can occur through two main possible pathways: (1) the so-called direct 4-electron pathway; and (2) indirect pathway via H2O2 intermediate [40]. In this study, we examined the ORR pathways catalyzed by F(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the H2O2 yield is increased significantly with decreasing the catalyst loading, reaching up to 16% when the catalyst loading is decreased to 100 µgcm−2. However, the peroxide yield on the Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD electrode under high catalyst loading of 500 µgcm−2 is found to be less than 4% over the potential range of −0.2 to 0.8V, which is slightly higher than that of Pt/C catalyst (0.15–0.55V). The corresponding electron transfer number is higher than 3.9, suggesting that the ORR proceeds mainly via a direct 4-electron pathway. 3.3 Catalytic ORR activities of Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts in acidic solution The electrocatalytic ORR activity of the as-prepared Fe(x)/N/S-PAD catalysts were also tested in acidic solution. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), the CV curves of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst indicate a significant catalytic activity with a pronounced ORR peak at 0.58V vs. SHE when the electrolyte (0.1M HClO4) is saturated with O2. The RDE polarization curves of Fe(0.5)/N/S-PAD, Fe(1.0)/N/S-PAD and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalysts are in agreement with the trends of their performance under alkaline conditions (Fig. 6(b)). The Fe(1.0)/N/S-PAD and Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD as shown in Fig. 7(b) exhibit a higher catalytic activity with a more positive half-wave potential (0.68V) and much higher current density (7.4mAcm−2 at 0.3V) than those of reported N-doped graphene and nanostructured carbon catalysts [41,42]. Moreover, the Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD exhibits an ORR process involving almost a 4-electron transfer pathway (n=3.87～3.94) over the potential range of 0.0–7.5V as shown in Fig. 7(d)), with low H2O2 yields of 2.3～4.0%. Although the half-wave potential of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD (800 µgcm−2) is still ∼100mV more negative than Pt/C (Fig. 7(c)), these results are very promising, since one of the problems typically plaguing non-precious cathode catalysts is their high hydrogen peroxide generation (H2O2), which is the result of the (2×2)e− mechanism, leading to severe corrosion of the carbonaceous catalyst, and even of the membrane and ionomer [43]. Therefore, the low H2O2 yield renders Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD more stable for long-running processes with a low risk of deactivation. 3.4 Durability of N/S-Fe-HPC in both alkaline and acidic electrolytes The electrocatalyst’s stability during ORR in both corrosive acidic and alkaline media is also an important factor in its applications. To evaluate the stability of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst, the ORR performance change before and after the accelerated durability tests (ADTs) were carried out with cycling within a potential range of 0.6–1.0V in O2-saturated 0.1M HClO4 (Fig. 8 (a and b)). After 5000 continuous cycles, the half-wave potential E 1/2 exhibits a small negative shift of about 19mV (Fig.8(b)). However, the E 1/2 shift of Pt/C catalyst is almost 170mV after the ADTs (Fig.8(a)), suggesting that this Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst has a much better durability than commercial Pt/C under the same test conditions. In alkaline solution saturated by O2, Fig. 8(c and d) show the durability results obtained by cycling Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst and Pt/C between 0.6 and 1.0V at 50mVs−1. After 5000 continuous potential cycles, the half-wave potential E 1/2 of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst exhibits almost no negative shift (Fig. 8 (d)),whereas the Pt/C gives a negative shift of more than 41mV in E 1/2 (Fig. 8(c)), suggesting the excellent durability of Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst in alkaline medium as well. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of ORR electrocatalysts composited by Fe, N, S and C (abbreviated as Fe(x)/N/S-PAD, x =0.05. 0.25, 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5, respectively, which are the weight ratio of FeSO4 7H2O/PAD) are synthesized using a two-step method in which home-made silica colloid as template, nitrogen-enriched polyquaternium and FeSO47H2O as N, C and Fe, S sources. Both porous structure and surface functionality of the catalysts, characterized by TEM, Raman spectroscopy, BET and XPS analysis, are realized by simply tuning the amount of FeSO4 7H2O, resulting in high catalytic ORR activity and stability in both alkaline and acidic media. It is identified that the outstanding ORR performance of such a catalyst is strongly associated with well-defined micro- and meso-porous structures, high BET surface area, and homogeneous distribution of Fe/N/S active sites, which afford abundant effective active sites and facilitate the electrolyte/reactant diffusion during the oxygen reduction process. Therefore, the Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD catalyst exhibits the most promising alternatives to Pt/C, implying that this catalyst could be used for catalyzing cathode ORR in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, alkaline fuel cells, and metal–air batteries. coredata.dc:description: Non-precious Fe/N/S-composited hierarchically porous carbon materials (Fe(x)/N/S-PAD, PAD: poly(acrylamide-co-diallyldimethyl ammonium chlor), x: the weight ratio of FeSO4 7H2O/PAD) are synthesized using a facile silica colloid template approach with FeSO4 7H2O as Fe and S sources, and PAD as N source, respectively. A simultaneous creation of porous structures and surface functionalities (Fe, N and S) of such catalysts is realized just by simply tuning the weight ratio of FeSO4 7H2O and PAD in the synthetic precursors. As a result, a series of catalyst samples with high oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity/stability are obtained, demonstrating the promotion role of FeSO4/PAD ratio in synthesizing high-performing catalysts. Particularly, a catalyst (Fe(1.5)/N/S-PAD) with a trace Fe content down to 1.0wt.% is tested to be superior to a commercial Pt/C catalyst in alkaline media and exhibits impressive ORR performance in acidic media. Combined with characterization results such as TEM, Raman spectra, BET and XPS analysis, it is found that the well-defined micro- and meso-porous structure play the key role in enhancing catalytic ORR performance rather than the final total N contents in the carbon. Regarding the stability of such a catalyst, test using cyclic voltammetry for 5000 cycles in O2-saturated solution shows a negligible degradation rate when compared with Pt/C one, suggesting that this catalyst could be used for catalyzing the high-performing cathode ORR in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, alkaline fuel cells and metal–air batteries.
coredata.dc:title: Fe/N/S-composited hierarchically porous carbons with optimized surface functionality, composition and nanoarchitecture as electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction
